quoteFirst: The hospital steamer on which myself and two other ladies took passage to Pittsburg Landing from Cairo, Ill., reaching Savannah, Tenn., eight miles below there,
quoteLast: , April 7. There we heard the news of the terrible battle that had been fought the day before. Some said: “The Union army is defeated and driven to the very banks of the river, and are all likely to be captured to-day.
title: Under the guns
author: Wittenmyer, Annie, 1827-1900; Grant, Julia Dent, 1826-1902 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Another authority gives the following list:--Evening, when the cattle return to the kraal just before sunset; night-fall, or the hour for gossip, before the people go to bed about 8 o’clock; then night, midnight, and the time when the buffaloes go to drink (
quoteLast: ), this latter is the hour before the sun rises; then ‘the blood-red period’ or ‘the time when the sun decorates the sky’, this is the hour when the first rays of the sun redden the heavens; after that morning, when the sun has risen.
title:
Primitive Time-reckoning
A study in the origins and first development of the art of counting time among the primitive and early culture peoples
author: Nilsson, Martin P. (Martin Persson), 1874-1967; Fielden, F. J., 1882- [Translator]

quoteFirst: Passports were strictly demanded at this time on leaving as well as on entering France. When I reached Calais I found that the boat (and even that boat one with no passengers) would leave
quoteLast: , after the arrival of mails by sea. The inspection of my passport could only take place, I was told, when the boat was starting.
title: The Life of the Rt. Hon. Sir Charles W. Dilke, Volume 1
author: Gwynn, Stephen Lucius, 1864-1950; Tuckwell, Gertrude M. [Editor]

quoteFirst: Pettigrew moved with Burguin's and Leventhorpe's regiments for that point, leaving a strong force and two guns at Whitehall. The train that took Rodgers did not return until
quoteLast: , and left soon after with troops. Seeing them off, I started on horseback with staff and rode to Goldsboro, and reached there at 9 A.M. and reported to Gen. Smith.
title:
Two Wars: An Autobiography of General Samuel G. French
Mexican War; War between the States, a Diary; Reconstruction Period, His Experience; Incidents, Reminiscences, etc.
author: French, Samuel Gibbs, 1818-1910

quoteFirst: No sooner had the ship got to sea than the skipper arranged a three-watch system, whereby Frank had the first watch from 8 P.M. till midnight, Mr. Wilson the middle watch, and the mate from 4 A.M. to 8 A.M., thus giving each of the officers a long spell of rest and recreation, as well as a chance to feel their power of independent command. And as the captain invariably rose
quoteLast: , he was able to keep his eye upon the mate and see that he did nothing wrong, but he never actively interfered. What he said to the mate in the privacy of his cabin no one but themselves ever knew, but it was doubtless something very stern and searching. Yet it had no effect whatever.
title: Frank Brown, Sea Apprentice
author: Bullen, Frank Thomas, 1857-1915; Twidle, Arthur, 1865-1936 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Unexpectedly,
quoteLast: , a violent sandy and misty wester began to blow; and all fancied that we had set sail to the south. Quite the contrary! The engine was still under repair.
title: The Land of Midian (Revisited) — Volume 1
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteFirst: Early one morning, a few days after Admiral Ho’s departure, the camp was roused by a sudden alarm.
quoteLast: , when it was still pitch dark, we were awakened by the sound of heavy firing in the Chinese territory. The continuous rattle of small arms and the deeper booming of field‐guns were distinctly audible.
title: The Land of the Boxers; or, China under the Allies
author: Casserly, Gordon, 1869-1947

quoteFirst: Riding home in the Livery Hacks
quoteLast: , the Merry-Makers would be all in, but much gratified to know that Vienna and Paree had nothing on them as regards Rough House.
title: Ade's Fables
author: Ade, George, 1866-1944; McCutcheon, John T. (John Tinney), 1870-1949 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: It was Sunday night when we saw the enemy. We were ready for action, but were lying down to have a rest, when orders came to stand at our posts. It was
quoteLast: on Monday when we started to fire; we were at it all day till six p.m., when we started to advance. Then the bugle sounded the charge, and the cavalry and infantry charged like madmen at the enemy; then the enemy fell back about forty miles, so we held them at bay till Wednesday, when the enemy was reinforced.
title: In the Firing Line: Stories of the War by Land and Sea
author: Adcock, Arthur St. John, 1864-1930

quoteFirst: When we left Bellagio, the two Misses Hawker, often our companions in Rome, accompanied us. We ascended the Splugen from Chiavenna in pitch darkness, till,
quoteLast: , the diligence entered upon the snow cuttings, and we proceeded for some time between walls of snow, often fifteen feet high. At last we stopped altogether, and in a spot where there was no refuge whatever from the ferocious ice-laden wind.
title: The Story of My Life, volumes 1-3
author: Hare, Augustus J. C. (Augustus John Cuthbert), 1834-1903

quoteFirst: Diurnal changes of pressure are proportionally much smaller in amount than changes of temperature, and are to be observed as a regular phenomenon only in the tropics, or elsewhere during very settled weather. There are usually two maxima daily, about 10 A.M. and 10 P.M., and two minima occurring
quoteLast: and 4 P.M. It is only in rare cases that the total barometric range exceeds 0.10 inch, very frequently it is not greater than 0.04 inch.
title:
Hints to Travellers, Scientific and General, Vol. 2
Tenth edition, revised and corrected
author: Royal Geographical Society (Great Britain); Reeves, Edward Ayearst, 1862-1945 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Durazzo, starting
quoteLast: and generally turning into camp between 6 and 7, long after the short winter afternoons had closed in, so that we had to find our way round our new camping ground in the dark. The weather had got considerably warmer, although the nights were still bitterly cold, and quite a scorching sun used to come out for a few hours in the middle of the day, and this took it out of the tired men a good deal.
title: An English woman-sergeant in the Serbian Army
author: Sandes, Flora, 1876-1956; Grujić, Slavko J., 1871-1937 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Temperature, in summer, commences its diurnal elevation
quoteLast: , also, and rises till about 2 P.M. From that time it falls with very little variation till 4 o'clock the next morning. It has but one maximum and one minimum in the twenty-four hours.
title: The Philosophy of the Weather. And a Guide to Its Changes
author: Butler, T. B. (Thomas Belden), 1806-1873

quoteFirst: Pettigrew moved with Burguin's and Leventhorpe's regiments for that point, leaving a strong force and two guns at Whitehall. The train that took Rodgers did not return until
quoteLast: , and left soon after with troops. Seeing them off, I started on horseback with staff and rode to Goldsboro, and reached there at 9 A.M. and reported to Gen. Smith.

quoteFirst: The men had a drop of rum when we got back, and it was
quoteLast: when I crawled into my flea bag. A family of beetles played, “Come and sit on my chair” across my toes, and an old brown rat wanted to keep me company.
title: A Soldier's Diary
author: Scott, Ralph

quoteFirst: And as travellers will naturally go up the Hudson river by day, and then on from Albany by night train,* seeing that there is nothing to be seen at Albany, and that these trains have excellent sleeping accommodation--a lady, or indeed a gentleman, should always take a double sleeping-berth, a single one costs half a dollar, and a double one a dollar. This outlay has nothing to do with the travelling ticket;--it will follow that he, she, or they will reach Niagara at
title: The West Indies and the Spanish Main
author: Trollope, Anthony, 1815-1882

quoteFirst: The earliest meal should be given at
quoteLast: or as soon as it is light, and then regularly throughout the day, every four hours.
title: Wild Ducks: How to Rear and Shoot Them
author: Oates, W. Coape

quoteFirst: Petersburg suffered little in the evacuation.  Its mayor and council surrendered it
quoteLast: of the 3d.  The besieging army, so long striving for its possession, was not permitted to enter it.
title: Slavery and four years of war
author: Keifer, Joseph Warren, 1836-1932
